moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 g6 3. e3 Bg7 4. Bd3 O-O: This is a good counter from Black, who has played fairly passively until now.
I thought White would be somewhat better here when I envisioned this position, but I think the correct evaluation is even.  The pawn structure is even since it will be difficult for White to hold the extra pawn.
moves.25... Qd5 26. Qe2 Kf8 27. a4 c4 28. Be4: I'm not sure that exchanging Queens was the right way to play this.  White should probably try to use their activity to gain material.
moves.34... Nxe6 35. Bc6 Nc7 36. Nd4 Bc1 37. N: Now White can hang on to the extra pawn, but it's not clear if anything can be done with it in an ending with opposite color Bishops.
moves.40... h6 41. Kf2 g5 42. g3 Kg6 43. Kf3 B: I don't see a clear way to progress unless my opponent makes an error.  The Black pawns can't be touched by my Bishop and there is no way for my King to penetrate Black's position.
moves.49. Kg4 Bc5 50. hxg5 hxg5 51. Kf3 Bd6 52: My opponent does not lose their nerve and make an unforced error.  My extra pawn comes to nothing.  Draw.
